title: Adelaide Sanchez Manuscript Collection, 1901 - 1973
description: "The scope & content includes the Sanchez Family and Genealogy, awards and certificates, pictures of family & friends, personal letters to & from her, newspaper articles about her, newspaper articles, manuscripts and copy by her." (SAHS, Minorcan Resources)

subject: Personal Papers; Genealogy; Correspondence; Photographs; Awards

title: Jose Simeon Sanchez, 1797 - 1853
description: "This collection contains valuable records dating back to 1790. Also included is the marriage contract from 1787 between Francisco Xavier Sanchez and the parents of Maria del Carmen Hill. The Bible included in the collection served as a record for the births and deaths of members of the family such as the Lorings and the Oates'. The correspondence deals mainly with Jose Simeon's activities as a politician and public server. The most significant subjects covered in this collection are the claims for the war of 1812-1813, land grants, real estate sales, mortgages, elections, tax collections, census, statistics, sale of slaves and politics. There is also personal correspondence, financial reports, records of money transactions, tax collector receipts and marshall documents in this collection." (SAHS, Minorcan Resources)
creator: Jose Simeon Sanchez, 1797-1853
subject: Personal Papers; Genealogy; Marriage Contracts; Land Claims; Real Estate; Slavery; Tax Records; Political Correspondence
source: Manuscripts Collection, St Augustine Historical Research Library

title: The Patriot War Papers and Patriot War Claims, 1812-1846
description: "On June 6, 1988 the Patriot War Papers were rediscovered by the archivist at the St. Augustine Historical Society. These documents were found at the archives of the St. Johns County Courthouse by Mr. Mike Sheehan while emptying the drawers containing the Civil Court records from 1821 to the 1950's. Since August 1987 these records have been sent to the Historical Society to be catalogued, indexed and stored." (SAHS, Minorcan Resources)
creator: Clerk of the Circuit Court of St. Johns County
subject: Patriot War; Legal Documents; U.S. Territorial Florida; Court Archives
source: Manuscripts Collection, St Augustine Historical Research Library

title: Medicis Family Papers
description: "The core element of this collection is the 11/11/1849 Last Will & Testament of Antonica Medicis, widow of Francis I. Medicis, just prior to her death. The follow-up document dated 11/31/1849 is the St Augustine Probate Office executing the Will following her death. Other original documents of interest include: the purchase of the Francis Medicis property in 1820, the purchase of a slave named Abraham DuPont by Emanuell Medicis on 02/02/1843, as well as several additional documents of closure on shared properties among the Medicis children going through the 1860s." (SAHS, Minorcan Resources)
creator: SAHS, Medicis Family
subject: Personal Papers; Genealogy; Probate Records; Slavery; Property Records; St. Augustine History
source: Manuscripts Collection, St Augustine Historical Research Library

Bryant, Dean P.; McMullin, John; Prescott, Samuel H.; Sanchez, Earnest F." (SAHS, Minorcan Resources)

title: Pablo Sabate Account Book
description: "This file consists of an account book of Pablo Sabate. One portion of the book is Sabate's account book dated 1804-1813. Another portion is a list of repayments to Sabate dated 1807-1811. This log book is in very fragile condition, binding is gone. The log lists, in ledger form, amount borrowed per month from Pablo Sabate. The entire book is hand written in Spanish and lists many members of the St. Augustine community labeled at the top of each page." (SAHS, Minorcan Resources)
creator: Pablo Sabate

title: St. Elmo W. Acosta
description: "69 pages (11x17in.) copies of newspaper clippings, cartoons and photos (many clippings/page) of the important and interesting career of St. Elmo (Chic) Acosta and his family during his long term role as Mayor of Jacksonville and his following duties in the Florida House of Representatives. He was the visionary force in the important development of early Jacksonville, and the primary force responsible for it's first major bridge across the St. Johns River, the Acosta Bridge." (SAHS, Minorcan Resources)
creator: SAHS, Adrienne (Mrs.Austin) Hollis, St. Elmo W. Acosta, 1875-1947

title: Juan Villalonga Judicial Proceeding
description: "This is a 16-page manuscript Spanish document regarding the trial and punishment of Juan Villalonga for hosting late-night dances for people of color. In the book Black Society in Spanish Florida, Jane Landers writes on page 94 "Black men joined in gambling and card games such as naipes in local taverns and men and women, free and enslaved, attended dances and dress balls. The upper floor of Juan Villalonga house on St. George Street (now part of the restored Spanish Quarter in St. Augustine) proved a popular venue for these dances for more than 20 years. Filis and Felipe Edimboro hosted dances there in the 1790s, and although periodic legislation attempted to prohibit late night dances for "people of color" in 1813, the government sentenced Villalonga, who by then had become a barrio commissioner, to eight days' house arrest for violating the useless ban." (SAHS, Minorcan Resources)
creator: Juan Villalonga, 1746-1821
subject: Judicial Records; Racial Policies; Social Life; Black History; St. Augustine History; Villalonga House
source: Manuscripts Collection, St Augustine Historical Research Library

Walters used a number of these letters for their article, "Indian Fighter, Confederate Soldier, Blockade Runner and Scout, the Life and Letters of Jacob E. Mickler" in volome 34 of El Escribano: The St Augestine Journal History. Letters are annotated in some places." (SAHS, Minorcan Resources)

Both are for the amount of $7.00, received by Joseph T. Pacetti, city treasurer and collector." (SAHS, Minorcan Resources)

title: William J. Sanchez Affidavit
description: "This is a notarized affidavit from William J. Sanchez, descended from Jesse Fish on his mother's side. Sanchez states that he (along with his father for a time) has owned Fish's Island (today known as Fish Island) since 1869. He sold the island in 1925 to A.L. Pamies. The document was signed and notarized by M.L. Stephen, a notary public in Florida, on March 6, 1925. The document was also filed and recorded in the public records of St. Johns County by Carl Markel, clerk of the circuit court, on September 12, 1984." (SAHS, Minorcan Resources)
creator: William J. Sanchez
subject: Fish Island; Jesse Fish; Land Ownership
source: Manuscripts Collection, St Augustine Historical Research Library

title: Philip D. Rasico, Professor and Linguist: Creolization of Catalan in the Minorcan Story
description: Philip Rasico, Professor of Spanish and Catalan, Vanderbilt University, interviewed by Dr. Andreu on the "the rare, remaining Minorcan phrases spoken by the descendants of St. Augustine's Minorcan community."
creator: Darien Andreu, Philip Rasico, Roscoe Saunders
subject: Interview; Philip Rasico; Linguistics; The Minorcan Studies Project
source: <a href="https://minorcanstudiesproject.omeka.net/">The Minorcan Studies Project</a!

title: The Minorcan Community after Turnbull
description: Author Sandie Stratton details the struggles of the Minorcan colonists as they abandoned the Turnbull settlement in New Smyrna and made their way to St. Augustine. Sandie was adopted and raised in a Minorcan family and grew up in the St. Augustine area. Her research and studies of the Minorcan community and how they adjusted to life following the end of the Turnbull Settlement here in New Smyrna was engaging and thought provoking.
creator: Sandie Stratton
subject: Talk; New Smyrna; Turnbull Settlement
source: New Smyrna Museum of History

title: Dr. Andrew Turnbull prepares the New Smyrna Settlement
description: Author Lea Craig from "The Minorcan Experience" in St. Augustine discusses her research on the Turnbull Settlement. We learn about the indentured workers who suffered immense hunger and hardship before deciding to abandon the Smyrnea colony.
creator: Lea Craig
subject: Talk; New Smyrna; Turnbull Settlement
source: New Smyrna Museum of History

title: The Turnbull Canal System
description: It's called Canal Street because it actually had a canal built by the Turnbull settlers over 250 years ago. Explore the history and fate of New Smyrna Beach's historic canal system.
creator: New Smyrna Museum of History
subject: Talk; New Smyrna; Turnbull Settlement
source: New Smyrna Museum of History

title: Smyrnea Settlement: Archeology and History of an 18th Century British Plantation in East Florida

creator: Roger T. Grange, Jr. and Dorothy L. Moore
subject: New Smyrna; Turnbull Settlement; Archeology
source: New Smyrna Museum of History

title: Smyrnea Settlement 1767-1768
description: Jim Englebrecht presents another chapter in the dramatic story of Dr. Andrew Turnbull and his Smyrnea settlement.  Turnbull traveled the Mediterranean for over a year gathering colonists, supplies, and ships before the final voyage to Florida.
creator: Jim Englebrecht
subject: Talk; New Smyrna; Turnbull Settlement; Archeology
source: New Smyrna Museum of History

title: A British Frigate at anchor, Port Mahon, Minorca
description: View from the shore of a British frigate from the Port of Mahon. "Anton Schranz, father of the artist Giovanni, specialised in painting and engraving landscapes and seascapes, notably of Valetta in Malta. He lived most of his life in Minorca, where he produced similar compositions of Port Mahon, before moving to Malta in 1817. There he found patronage amongst British naval officers who bought his works as topographical souvenirs." (Sothebys)
creator: Anton Schranz, 1769–1839
subject: Paintings; Port Mahon
source: Wikimedia Commons

title: H.M.S. Caledonia clearing Port Mahon, Minorca

creator: Anton Schranz, 1769–1839
subject: Paintings; Port Mahon
source: Wikimedia Commons

title: A draught of the town and harbour of Mahon

creator: Anonymous

source: The British Museum

title: Magatzems al port de Maó
description: The painting depicts the port of Maó in the early 19th century, focusing on the area near the Costa de ses Voltes and the warehouses next to the Abundància ramp, where figures from all social classes are shown engaging in daily activities related to distillation, trade, and seafaring. Likely commissioned by Joan Basilini in homage to his father Alexandre Basilini, the work blends real and imagined architecture to highlight the family's influence and legacy, featuring over 150 characters, including a central figure believed to represent Alexandre himself.
creator: Anonymous
subject: Paintings; Port Mahon
source: Museu de Menorca
